Abyssinian: colors include ruddy, red, blue, or fawn
expressive face with a slightly concave profile.
Bengal: coat colors often in shades of brown, gold, or snow (white)
large almond-shaped eyes, usually green or gold
Birman: Color-pointed coat (darker coloration on ears, face, paws, and tail)
British Shorthair: Large, round eyes, often copper or gold in color
Egyptian Mau: characteristic "worried" expression due to the set of eyes and brow lines
coat colors include silver, bronze, and smoke
hind legs longer than the front legs, giving a "tippy-toe" appearance
Maine Coon: Prominent ruff of fur around the neck
Wide-set eyes, often with a piercing look
Ragdoll: Floppy and relaxed posture when held
V-shaped or an inverted "V" marking on the forehead
american bulldog: Typically white or white with patches of brindle, brown, or black
Moderate to long tail, thick at the base and tapering to a point
american pit bull terrier: ears that can be cropped or natural (half-prick or rose-shaped)
basset hound: tricolor coat (typically black, white, and brown)
pronounced dewlap (extra skin around the neck)
boxer: possibly wearing headgear (in some training or amateur contexts)
posture indicating a readiness to fight or defend
english cocker spaniel: Big, expressive eyes (often dark in color)
english setter: coat colors typically white with speckles of black, blue, lemon, orange, or brown
long ears hanging close to the head
german shorthaired: Coat color is typically liver (brown), liver and white, or liver roan
great pyrenees: Strong, muscular legs adapted for working and guarding livestock
Fluffy, plumed tail that is usually carried low or curled over the back
havanese: plume-like tail that curls over the back
japanese chin: Feathered, V-shaped ears that drop down
Black and white or red and white coat
keeshond: fur often in shades of grey, black, and cream
leonberger: strong and broad head with a slightly domed forehead
medium-length ears that hang close to the head
newfoundland: Thick, water-resistant double coat, typically black, brown, grey, or Landseer (black and white)
Drooping ears, relatively small and shaped like a triangle
Broad head with a strong and rounded skull
pomeranian: A plumed tail that curls over the back
pug: curled tail that often rests on the back
saint bernard: Distinctive reddish-brown "mask" around the eyes and ears
scottish terrier: Tail that is medium length and often carried straight or with a slight curve
Distinctive, wiry coat, often black, but can also be brindle or wheaten
shiba inu: curled tail that usually rests over its back
distinct coat colors, typically red, black and tan, or sesame (red with black-tipped hairs)
white fur on the chest, legs, and tip of the tail
staffordshire bull terrier: Strong, straight front legs and well-muscled hindquarters
wheaten terrier: a tail that is typically held upright or slightly curved
floppy ears that hang close to the head
yorkshire terrier: feathery tail that is usually carried slightly higher than the back
often has a topknot or hair tied up on the head
